title: TLCTC v2.0 — Agentic AI Tool Category Profiles
description: Reference data for agentic AI tool categories, mapping each to its consequence profile (primary DRE, velocity, scope, autonomy characteristics, and irreversibility). Layer 2 reference registry extension. These profiles enable consequence-side risk assessment: for each tool category an agent has access to, the organisation can evaluate the maximum damage potential.

metadata.source_paper: The Consequence Amplifier — Agentic AI on the Right Side of the Bow-Tie
metadata.author: Bernhard Kreinz
metadata.registry_type: Layer 2 — Reference Registry extension for agentic AI tool profiling

velocity_classes.description: TLCTC v2.0 Velocity Classes determine which control types are structurally viable at each speed.

VC-1.viable_control_mode: Strategic: log retention, threat hunting, strategic monitoring, policy review

VC-2.viable_control_mode: Tactical: SIEM alerting, analyst triage, guided response

VC-3.viable_control_mode: Operational: SOAR/EDR automation, rapid containment, prebuilt playbooks

VC-4.viable_control_mode: Real-Time: architecture, circuit breakers, rate-limits, hardening, automatic isolation

tool_profiles.description: Database connectors, document retrieval, search APIs, file system access, CRM/ERP integrations.
tool_profiles.scope_description: All connected data stores. Critical amplification factor: cross-system correlation — the agent can combine individually low-sensitivity data from multiple systems into high-sensitivity composite profiles.
tool_profiles.autonomy_description: Algorithmic data correlation, selective extraction, bulk aggregation without human guidance.
tool_profiles.irreversibility: Low recovery feasibility. Once data is read by the compromised process, confidentiality is permanently lost.
tool_profiles.key_consequence_metric: Maximum volume of records accessible within first 60 seconds, across all connected data stores.

recovery: Breach notification procedures (data exposure is irreversible)

tool_profiles.description: Code interpreters, shell access, CI/CD pipeline triggers, infrastructure-as-code deployments.
tool_profiles.consequence_velocity: VC-4 for individual actions; consequence chains can extend to VC-1 as deployed modifications accumulate undetected.
tool_profiles.scope_description: Execution environment and all dependencies. Code can create persistent, self-reinforcing damage: backdoors, monitoring suppression, application logic modification.
tool_profiles.autonomy_description: Self-modifying behaviour. Agent can generate novel code, adapt to defensive responses, establish persistence mechanisms that survive agent termination.
tool_profiles.irreversibility: Medium. Rollback possible for version-controlled systems, but undetected modifications to build pipelines or application logic may propagate through deployment cycles.
tool_profiles.key_consequence_metric: Number of systems reachable from execution context × types of modifications possible (config, code, data, infrastructure).
tool_profiles.cause_side_note: Code execution creates the #1→#7 pattern from the cause-side paper. The agent's designed code execution capability is #1; the generated code executing is FEC → #7.

limitation: Code review gates for generated code
containment: Kill switch on unexpected system calls

tool_profiles.description: Email clients, messaging platforms (Slack, Teams), social media APIs, customer notification systems.
tool_profiles.consequence_velocity: VC-4. Milliseconds per message. A compromised agent can send thousands of messages before any human detection.
tool_profiles.scope_description: All recipients and their networks. Each outbound message potentially creates a new victim. Scope amplification is maximal because the consequence propagates beyond organisational boundaries.
tool_profiles.autonomy_description: Adaptive content generation. Agent can personalise messages per recipient, vary content to avoid pattern detection, impersonate the organisation convincingly.
tool_profiles.irreversibility: High. Messages cannot be recalled after delivery. Reputational and legal damage is instantaneous upon receipt.
tool_profiles.key_consequence_metric: Maximum number of external communications sendable in 60 seconds × average recipient reach per message.

limitation: Delayed sending queues (impose VC-2 on outbound comms)
containment: Recipient anomaly detection (new addresses, bulk sends)

tool_profiles.description: Payment APIs, procurement systems, trading platforms, invoice processing, expense management.
tool_profiles.consequence_velocity: VC-4. Financial APIs are designed for speed. Settlement windows may provide limited recovery.
tool_profiles.scope_description: All connected financial systems. Transaction chaining across payment, procurement, and accounting systems.
tool_profiles.autonomy_description: Transaction chaining. Agent can initiate payments, modify invoices, and adjust records in coordinated sequences designed to avoid reconciliation detection.
tool_profiles.irreversibility: Very High. Instant payment systems: zero recovery window. Wire transfers: limited window (hours). Settled transactions: final.
tool_profiles.key_consequence_metric: Maximum monetary value transferable in 60 seconds = (per-transaction limit × maximum transactions per minute). If no cap exists, the answer is the agent's entire authorised payment authority.

tool_profiles.description: Cloud management consoles, DNS configuration, certificate management, container orchestration, network configuration.
tool_profiles.consequence_velocity: VC-4 for individual changes. Recovery is often VC-1 or VC-2 (hours to days) because infrastructure changes require careful rollback.
tool_profiles.scope_description: All dependent services. A single DNS change or certificate revocation cascades to all dependent services instantly. Scope amplification is maximal at infrastructure layer.
tool_profiles.autonomy_description: Cascading configuration changes. Agent can modify multiple infrastructure layers in sequence, creating compound failures that are difficult to diagnose and recover from.
tool_profiles.irreversibility: Medium–High. Rollback is possible but cascading effects complicate recovery. Incorrect recovery order can compound the outage.
tool_profiles.key_consequence_metric: Number of dependent services × average time to recover per service × cascade multiplication factor.

containment: Automated rollback on service health degradation
Independent monitoring (not modifiable by the agent)
recovery: Documented recovery order for multi-layer failures
Disaster recovery runbooks for agent-specific scenarios

risk_assessment_procedure: 1. Inventory all tools and integrations the agent has access to
2. Map each tool to a tool category profile above
3. For each profile, calculate the key_consequence_metric given the agent's specific permissions
4. Evaluate whether the 60-second maximum damage is within risk appetite
5. If not: reduce blast radius via limitation controls BEFORE deployment
6. Configure containment controls per the recommended_controls for each active tool category
7. Document recovery procedures, noting irreversibility constraints per tool category
